Title: Polynomials that never produce primes
Content:
This problem was given to me by an acquaintance during a basketball game. Define the sequence $a_n$ as follows: $$a_0=1, a_1=x+1, a_{n+2}=xa_{n+1}-a_n$$ Prove that there exists
infinitely many positive integers $x$ such that $a_n$ is never a
prime. This looks like a very interesting problem, but I haven’t made any progress at all. The only thing I have in regards is that the polynomials $T_n(\frac{x}2)$ satisfy the same recurrence relation, but do not have the same initial values. I think the problem should be true for any recurrent sequence of polynomials, but I cannot prove this. When I first read the problem, two well known theorems popped up in my mind: for a finite family of polynomials, there is a value at which they all assume a composite number, and any recurrent sequence is periodic modulo any number. So if we take $a_1, \cdots a_s$ , and assure that $a_i$ is composite and divisible by a prime $p_i$ . And if we let the periods of $a_n$ mod $p_i$ be $m_i$ . If we can assure somehow that: $\text{lcm}(m_1,\cdots,m_s)\le s$ , then we’d be done The source is: Korea Final Round $2019/3$ . The solution isn’t that hard and is motivated by the fact that: $a_na_{n+2}=a_{n+1}^2-(x+2).$
AcceptedAnswer: This is essentially the AOPS answer. The formula $a_na_{n+2}=a_{n+1}^2-(x+2)$ , which is a consequence of $\frac{a_{n+2}+a_n}{a_{n+1}}$ being constant motivates taking $x+2=a^2$ . Now: $a_na_{n+2}=(a_{n+1}-a)(a_{n+1}+a)$ If we can ensure that: $a_{n+2}>a_{n+1}+a$ then we’d be done, but it can be easily seen that this must be true. $a_{n+2}-a_{n+1}=(x-2)a_{n+1}+a_{n+1}-a_n>a_{n+1}-a_n>a_1-a_0=a^2-2>a$
